Question: Making a text file available to all methods in Java: :I have a simple single Java file, that has main method and a bunch of other methods. I'd like to open a text file in my main method but keep it open and append to it in my other methods in my java code. what is the best way of doing it in Java. 
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer: <<<api>>>: File
<<<code>>>: 
File file = new File("path_to_your_file");
PrintWriter pw = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(file, true));

<<<explanation>>>: 
The File class in Java is used to represent a file or a directory in the file system. Here, we are creating a new File object with the path of the file you want to open.

PrintWriter class in Java is used to write text to a character-output stream. Here, we are creating a new PrintWriter object that takes a FileWriter object as an argument. The second argument, true, makes the FileWriter append mode.

To use this PrintWriter in other methods, you can simply pass it as an argument to those methods. For example:

public void someMethod(PrintWriter pw) {
    pw.write("Some text");
}

And then you can call this method from your main method like this:

public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
    File file = new File("path_to_your_file");
    PrintWriter pw = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter(file, true));
    someMethod(pw);
    pw.close();
}

This way, the PrintWriter will be available to all methods in your Java code, and you can use it to write to the file from any of them. Don't forget to close the PrintWriter after you're done with it to free up system resources.
